snippet: Uber has been trying to find a way to operate legally in the country since prosecutors indicted its chief executive and its Korean unit in December.
abstract: Uber asks South Korean government to register its drivers, part of company's efforts to continue to operate in country despite legal challenges; company's South Korean unit and its chief executive Travis Kalanick were indicted by South Korean authorities in 2014 for violating local transportation laws.
lead_paragraph: Uber has been trying to find a way to operate legally in the country since prosecutors indicted its chief executive and its Korean unit in December.

headline.main: Uber Tries to Ease Concerns in South Korea
headline.print_headline: Uber Seeks to Overcome Legal Hurdles in South Korea
